hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the wall. Each row represents a series of bricks, and the widths of these bricks can vary. Visualize how a vertical line would interact with these rows.
Remember that the line can only cross bricks, not edges. This means you need to consider where the edges of each brick are located within each row.
Consider how you can represent the positions of the edges of the bricks. You could maintain a running total of widths as you iterate through each row.
As you calculate the positions of the edges, think about using a hashmap (or dictionary) to count how many rows have edges at each position. This will help you determine where to draw the line.
When you encounter the edges of the bricks, update your hashmap with the count of edges at that position. For example, if you have a brick of width 2, you would add an edge at position 2.

After processing all rows, the positions in your hashmap will tell you how many rows can be crossed if you draw a vertical line at that position. The goal is to find the position with the maximum count.
To find the minimum number of crossed bricks, subtract the maximum count of edges from the total number of rows. This gives you the least number of bricks crossed.
Consider edge cases, such as when there is only one row or when all bricks are of the same width. How would your approach handle these scenarios?
Make sure to account for the constraint that the total width of each row is the same. This will ensure your edge positions are valid across all rows.
Finally, implement the logic to iterate through the wall, update the hashmap, and calculate the minimum crossed bricks. Ensure your solution is efficient given the constraints.

questionNotes: Each row has the same total width, which is crucial for determining valid edge positions.
The line cannot be drawn just along the vertical edges of the wall.
Return the minimum number of crossed bricks, not the positions of the edges.
